div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,591] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial houses and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 3 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deposited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

div.head: "EN COMMANDITE" COMPANIES.
div.p: It is a curious fact that the system of “En Commandite" Companies, so extensive in Ger- many, France, and America, has never been legalised in England, the country where it might have been expected to specially flourish. The efforts at legislation in this direction have been numerous, extending over many years up to the present session of Parliament The reason for their failure appears to be the desire to maintain the position and responsibility of the British trader, which has been so high and honourable in the past. It is feared that, if private firms have partners whose capital in the undertaking is limited, the credit of the business community will suffer, which of course would be a very serious matter to the trade of the country. At the time when our great bankers largely adopted the Limited Liability system similar fears were expressed, and, were it not for the terrible lesson of the Glasgow Bank failure, would probably have prevailed to prevent this important change. It is true that the trade creditor deserves the protection of Parliament, but he is generally able to name his terms, and if he gives long credit it must and should be at his own risk. But his interest as well as his protection should also be the care of Parliament, and it is sorely clear that so important an extension to facilities for trading is very much for his good. As it is at present, an enterprising man desiring to trade on his own account starts with little of no capital, and has to be trusted on his ability and character alone; would not those who supply his goods be in a better position if such a man could more readily command the capital of a sleeping partner, even if such capital be limited in amount and the sum of it clearly made known? In almost every case each additional capital would be an advantage to both sides. Again, take the case of a wealthy firm whose elder members are taking a less active part in the management, but are ready to leave a substantial but limited amount to be risked by those who are actively carrying on the business. It is to be assumed that the capital would be sufficient, as otherwise such a partner would be wilfully crippling his own investment. Instead of an unknown amount of private capital, which sometimes proves altogether overrated, the creditors have assurance of a definite and adequate sum left in the business, and the partner can retire with peace of mind knowing that such amount of capital as remains to him outside the firm is not being ventured.

Probably in no country except America are the two conditions, necessary for the extensive use of the “En Commandite” Company system, so present as in Great Britain ; i e. ample capital to venture, and the desire to help to success in life active and able men. The power of this fine trait in the national character, so beneficial in the past, is paralyzed at the present day by the dread of the capitalist of being “construed” a partner in an unlimited business not managed by himself.

The able report of the Commission recom- mends the legalization of “En Commandite” Companies, but, (although Mr. Worthington Evans points out in his minority report that a simple alteration of the present acts enabling two or more instead of seven or more would probably be sufficient), relegates the matter to the Partnership Acts, which they suggest should be altered so as to make "Eu Comman- dite” partnerships legal. They are probably right in this recommendation, as the addition of "Limited” to the title of private firms, and the trouble of conforming with the require- ments of the Joint Stock Companies Acts, would be a considerable deterrent, and a spe- cial Act for the purpose with or without registration of some kind would probably meet the case best.

This recommendation has already been acted upon and a will is pending before Parliament entitled the “Limited Partnershin’s bill" to carry it out. In Egypt, it is hardly necessary to add, the "Société en Commandite" as well as the “Société Anonyme” on the French model both exist governed by the commercial code of 1888 and its subsequent amendments.

div.head: ENGLAND AND GERMANY.
AN ENTENTE SUGGESTED
div.p: London, September 5.

An inspired article published in the "Deutsche Revue” regarding Anglo-German relations declares that a very frank and un- constrained discussion on the general inter- national situation took place at the meeting between King Edward and the Emperor William, and suggests that the meeting paved the way for an Anglo-German entente.

The “Times,” commenting on the article states that it sees no reason for a quarrel with Germany, but that the relations between the two countries cannot, under the present circumstances, acquire the same intimacy as those existing between France and England. (Reuter)

div.head: THE CHANNEL FLEET.
NEW COMMANDER.
div.p: London, September 5.

The "Daily News” announces that Lord Charles Beresford will assume the command of the Channel Fleet in March next. It is officially stated that Rear-Admiral Barry will succeed Admiral Lambton in the command of the third cruiser squadron. Rear- Admiral Robinson has been appointed Super- intendent of Portsmouth Dockyard. Rear- Admiral Callaghan has been attached to the Channel Fleet. (Reuter)

div.head: FRANCE AND THE POPE.
div.p: Paris, September 5.
The French Bishops have telegraphed to the Pope expressing their gratitude for the Eucyclical and promising obedience despite perils and trials. (Reuter)

div.head: TRANSVAAL WAR LOAN.
A POLITICAL BARGAIN.
div.p: London, September 5.

The "Times,” in a financial article written by a well-informed person, says that surprise is expressed in the City at the absense of protest against the Government’s action in relinquishing the £30,000,000 Transvaal war loan for a new loan of £4,000,000, and suggests that it forms the basis of a political bargain between the Government and the mining magnates: "If you make no fuss about the Chinese labour question we will relieve you of your liability under the £30,000,000 war loan.” (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN JEWS -
EDUCATIONAL PRIVILEGES.
div.p: St. Petersburg, September 5.
The Council of the Empire has sanctioned the bill authorising Jews to open schools according to the rules in force. (Havas)

div.head: THE FAR EAST.
RUSSIAN CONSULATES GENERAL.
div.p: St. Petersburg, September 5.
Russia will establish consolates-general at Harbin, Mukden. Kirin. Tsitsihar, and Dalny, replacing the existing agencies of the Foreign Office at those places. (Reuter)

div.head: NATAL TROUBLES
FORCES TO BE DISBANDED.
div.p: Durban, September 5.
It is stated that all the field forces in Natal will be disbanded on the 7th instant. (Reuter)

div.head: GERMAN MANŒUVRES.
div.p: London, September 5.
The Duke of Connaught and General Max- well have gone to Germany in order to attend the manœuvres. (Reuter)

div.head: REAL ESTATE TRUST CO.
ARREST OF OFFICIALS.
div.p: New York, September 5.

Three officials of the Real Estate Trust Company have been arrested. They are charg- ed with defrauding the depositors to the ex- tent of millions of dollars. It is estimated that the failure will exceed 10,000,000 dollars. (Reuter)

div.head: LADY BANNERMAN’S FUNERAL
div.p: London, September 5.

The funeral of Lady Bannerman took place this afternoon at Meigle before a large and representative attendance, including, amongst others Messrs. Asquith and Morley, Lords Tweedmouth and Portsmouth, and Mr. Glad- stone. The ceremony was simple, but most impressive. Sir Edward Colebrooke represented the King. (Reuter)

div.head: PRINCESS EITEL.
div.p: Berlin, September 5.
Princess Eitel is encsinte. (Havas)
The subscription for the Mecca conduit repair fund amount to P.T. 1,536,970.
The Ministry of Public Works has complet- ed the construction of the Government School at Benha.
The Ministry of the Interior has authorised Mr. Antoine Makas to follow the trade of a chemist in Egypt.
An Egyptian actor, Sheikh Salama el Hegazi who has bad invitations to go to Italy for several years past, will probably go there this year.
The total credit of L.E. 1,000 for the erec- tion of posts between Roseires and El Obeid for the repression of the slave trade has already been totally expended.

To avoid rabies, dogs travelling on the State railways are to be placed in a separate van, and will pay half the third-class fare, as pre- scribed by article 81 of the rules. In cases where there is no objection among the passengers dogs may travel with them provided they have paid their fare.

In his recent report the Acting British Consul at Damascus remarks, with regard to possible openings for British trade in Da- mascus, that although cheapness is of first importance and British merchants find it wise to make strict terms, British wares enjoy a good name there.

Persons wishing to receive their correspon- dence at the distribution windows of Post Offices are earnestly requested to take the necessary steps to have such letters addressed "Poste Restante.” Those who subscribe to special boxes will facilitate sorting by having the number of their box put on their address.

Our attention bas been called by a cor- respondent to the fact that Sunday dosing is not the rule with all the members of the British community. If these delinquent mem- bers of a Sabbatarian community fail to sup- port the movement by offering an example, how can one expect that other nations will put up their shutters on the Lord’s Day?

Rumour has it that the Government has requested the Hellenic Consular authorities to expel two—who are Greek subjects - of the three men who attacked two British officers and the police in the Opera square on Monday evening last. The third being a local subject will be tried by the native tribunals. It is expected that the Hellenic Consular authorities will giant this request.

Nothing thus far has resulted from the search made in the three sakiehs and cesspools of the maison Ciccolani, and there was some talk of sluicing the canal to allow of the bottom being searched. No more than fifteen small piastres were found in the house, but this is explained by the testi- mony of witnesses that Scopelitis carried all his valuables on his person. The native Court is having the procès verbal translated for the Hellenic Consulate.

Among the new papyri published by Messrs. Grenfell and Hunt, for the Egypt Explora- tion Pond, from Hibeh in the Fayour, is one certainiug a fragment of Euripides and some extracts to whom the author is not definitely assigned. Among the latter occurs the sen- tence qouted by St Paul, and supposed to be from Euripides or Menander “Evil communica- tions corrupt good manners.” The probability is that as the largest literary fragment on this papyrus is from Euripides the other cita- tions are from his works and therefore the attribution of this aphorism to him was correct.

The recent raid on an Italian gambling hell in Cairo has led to a little passage of arms between the "Journal du Caire” and the “Progrès." The former concluded its notice of the raid with the following apostrophe : Italiens ne von» essayez pas dans les maisons de jeux, c’est on privilège réservé aux grecs! Voyez, combien peu ces messieurs sont tra- cassée. Et cependant la police veille.” This arouses the wrath of the ‘Progrès,” which qualifies these remark's as "commentaires qui sont tout à fait déplacés, les nationalités n'ayant rien a voir dans un délit de droit common."

A number of Government officials in receipt of salaries of L.E. 9 per month have submitted a petition to Lord Edward Cecil, president of the Commission on the salaries of Government officials, stating that they did not benefit by the raising of salaries of the subordinate staff effected last winter, and requesting that their case may be seriously considered by the com- mission, as owing to a rumour to the effect that the present Commission will deal only with salaries of L.E. 10 par mensem and up- wards, they fear they may be overlooked. Lord Cecil promised to take their petition into consideration.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Ap- plications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretory, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: THE LATE PRINCE IBRAHIM.
IMPOSING FUNERAL.
PUBLIC MOURNING.
div.p: The body of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim Pasha arrived at Cairo from Alex- andria on Tuesday night, where it was met by Prince Mohamed Ali, Aly Saddik Bey, Suh- Governor of Cairo, Hassan Pasha Assem, Maitre Meizbach, and Captain Blakeney. On its arrival it was placed in one of the offices on platform No. 4, to await the performance of the final rites.

The funeral procession was timed to leave the railway station at 4 p.m. Some time before that hour small crowds began to collect in the streets and on the balconies which would be passed en route, and the station square was only made passable by the excellent arrange- ments which bad been made by the police authorities. From many building flags hung at half-mast and not a few of then were dressed with crape.

On the station platform representatives from all the Ministries, Administrations, public offices, the Egyptian Army, the Army of Occupation, and many private offices had assembled, while friends and servants of the deceased Prince were present in large num- bers to pay their last respects to a much admired man and beloved master. The plat- form, indeed, was crowded with those who had come to pay their last act of homage to a Prince who had met his death so prematurely.

At ten minutes to four sailors of H H. the Khedive’s Yacht Mahroussa raised the bier aloft to carry it to the gun carriage which was waiting in the station equate, and the crowd filed slowly out behind it. On the coffin were placed the Prince's sword, tonic, and decora- tions.

The procession was headed by a Cavalry company of the Egyptian Army, which was preceded by the Cavalry band. Next came a large body of Ulema, Sheikhs, Dervishes, and other co-religionists of the regretted Prince, among whom mingled many Europeans, who desired to pay a final act of homage. Following behind the coffin were the carriages of the ladies of the bereaved family, the Khedivial family, and close acquaintances.

As the procession proceeded to the Imam el Sherafi Mosque it passed between dense crowds on either side. Far in advance of the bier one could hear the mournful strains of Cavalry band, and as this passed out of hearing the impressiveness of the sad procession was increased by the dull thuds of the accompany- ing crowds and the aspects of the silent onlookers. It was, indeed, a grand and solemn ceremony, from which no chanting yemeneeyeh or shrieking, dishevelled women detracted any of its solemnity.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will arrive in Constantinople next week either on Monday or Thursday.

div.head: THE HELBAWI AFFAIR.
div.p: Ibrahim Bey Helbawi has written to “Al Moayad" contradicting the statements made by "Al Minbar” in reference to the conduct of Prince Mohamed Aly Pasha towards the Bey on board the “Hohenzollern.” Helhawi Bey states that he did not ask to be permitted to meet the Prince nor did his Highness refuse to greet him, and he heard no cutting remarks from him as he never went near the Prince. As to the alleged statements made by the Prince to the Captain in reference to the Bey, he declares that the Prince had a special table, while he dined with the other Egyptian passengers at the ordinary table, where the Prince’s secretary frequently joined their party.

It appears from these statements that "Al Minbar’s” report is quite untrue, and whoever invented it did so for the purpose of putting either the Prince or Helbawi Bey in an in- vidious position before the public.

div.head: ULEMA BOARD OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The result of the annoul examination of the religious students by the Ulema Board of Alex- andria was published this morning at the Abou el Abbas mosque, where the prizes were distributed to the successful Talaba. The stu- dents are 530 in number,divided into 5 classes, of whom 429. or 81 per cent., were successful. A sum of P.T. 7,500 was distributed among the successful students, P.T. 1,500 being given to each class. The ceremony was attended by a large number of Ulema and notables, including the council of Al-Azhar University, the Gover- nor of Alexendria, Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, Kheri Pasha, President of the Khassa Wakfs, etc.
While a student, Mohamed Khattob, was being given his prize, be asked that the money should be given to a poor student as he was sufficiently gratified by his success in passing the examination.
Several speeches were made.

div.head: VILLA MARGHARITA AFFAIR.
div.p: The Attarin native court yesterday sen- tenced for attempted murder the Armenian who attacked Dr. Hassan Bey Moharrem at Villa Margharita Hotel a fortnight ago, to two years’ imprisonment with hard labour.

div.head: EGYPT FOR THE EGYPTIANS
PLAUSIBLE BUT MEANINGLESS.
STRIKING LIBERAL ARTICLE.,
div.p: The full text of the striking leading article in the "Daily Chronicle” dealing with the pan- Islamic agitation, a telegraphic summary of which we have already published, is now to hand. In it the writer says :—

We have heard a good deal lately, through the plausible pen of Mustapha Kamel, about "Egypt for the Egyptians.” The phrase has a taking ring about it, and has at various times caught the ear of enthasiastic friends of liberty in this country. It apparently attracts some Members of Parliament to day. But it is a phrase with no meaning so far as practical politics are concerned ; or rather the only meaning which would attach to it, if the formula were worked out, is sadly different. Nobody who dispassionately surveys the forces which move European politics can suppose that the idea of an independent Egypt—of an Egypt governed by Egyptians for Egyptians—is prac- ticable. The conditions, internal and external alike, which it would require, do not exist. Egypt is not as yet capable, by experience, training, or habits, to stand alone; and if she were, the interests and jealousies of other States would not allow her to do so. The real alternative to the British occupation is not "Egypt tor the Egyptians,” hat the retrocession of "Egypt to the Turks.” The formula thus translated should hardly sound attractive in Liberal ears. So we wrote a month ago. We return to the subject to-day because we find the same conclusion stated in the same phrases by the writer of an elaborate notice of Pan- Islamism in the "Temps.” The testimony of the French paper is the more valuable because the writer is not prepossessed in favour of the British administration in Egypt. He does not hesitate to blame it for a certain impolitic haughtiness and detachment. He blames the British officers, too — not very justly, we think—for stupidity in the recent affray at Donishwai. But he considers the whole situa- tion in an impartial spirit; he analyses the Pan-Islamic movement in Egypt ; and he arrives at the conclusion which we have stated. There is no question of "Egypt for the Egyp- tian"; except that in one sense, as our French critic handsomely acknowledges, the British occupation realises the phrase, for it adminis- ters the country in the interests, and to the great advantage, of the Egyptians. The aspira- tion which really lies behind the phrase, as Pan-Islamist agitators use it, is Egypt for the Turks.

Some people in this country have supposed that Lord Cromer’s recent dispatches exagge- rate the seriousness of the situation in Egypt. Why the man who knows Egypt best, and the motto of whose long administration there has been Patience, should have suddenly fallen into delusion, and caught an attack of un- necessary "nerves,” does not appear. The French writer, however, ridicules Mustapha Kamel’s reply to Lord Cromer, and confirms from his own personal inquiries the reality of the Pan-Islamist movement in Egypt. He has received two hundred replies from Europeans resident in the interior of the country. “We do not recognize the peasantry insecurity in- creases daily.” It is thus that he summarises the testimony of his informants. He attributes the new movement to the insidious campaign of the Pan-Islamist Press. These papers do not print a large number of copies; but if the reading public in Egypt be small, the hearing public is not. “In the village,” we are told, “a novel spectacle may in these days be seen. A large circle is formed around a man who harangues copiously. A singer or a traveling orator, no doubt? Not at all; this kind of ‘fiki’ is a reader of and commentator upon news- papers.” His reading and his commentaries may be imagined. The talk spreads from village goes round that the Europeans mean to destroy the religion of the Faithful, and that the Khalifa will declare a Holy War against England. It is in this way, according to the French inquirer, that fanaticism is diligently inspired. He traces the origin of inspiration to the Palace at Constantinople, which has, be it remembered, a permanent centre of influence in Cairo. The “Nationalists” (and in Egypt the former are for the most part the latter) have indeed two languages and sometimes “talk European”; but in the form in which their talk reaches the Egyptian peasant, it is an appeal to Mussulman fanaticism. This fact it is which explains what we called the other day “the Egyptian parados”- the paradox that while the peasant enjoys under British occupation unexampled prosperity, he yet chafes under it. It should be remembered also, as Lord Cromer has pointed out, that none of the younger men can any longer speak from per- sonar experience of the abuses which prevailed prior to the British occupation. In this state of things, Liberals in this country should be slow to give any encouragement to the enemies, open or concealed, of British rule, and to those who, deliberately or unconsciously, favour the alternative of Egypt for the Turks.

div.head: MOSQUE IN LONDON.
TO BE BUILT IN BAYSWATER.
div.p: The long projected London mo*mosque for the pan-Islamic colony resident in the metropolis, is soon to become an accomplished fact, and within a few years, when the building is com- pleted, the dwellers of Bayswater may hear the voice of the muczzin calling the hour of prayer from a gilded minaret worthy in beauty of the capitol of Islam.

The idea has long been cherished by the pan- Islamic colony in London, which numbers nearly 2,500, and about eighteen months ago definitive steps were taken, and a committee was formed to consider designs. The design eventually selected, is the work of the well- known architect, Mr. W.L. Chambers, of Waldorf chambers, who designed the small but beautiful mosque at Woking, Surrey, and who has made a life study of Eastern architecture.

Two or three sites are under consideration, but it is probable that one in the Bayswater- road will be eventually decided upon. The main desire of the committee is to secure a site which will afford an uninterrupted view of the morque. It will undoubtedly be one of the most beautiful and remarkable specimens of architecture to be seen near London.

The building will be 180 feet in length, and will have a frontage of 150 feet. The architect is desirous that the mosque should be con- structed of pure white material, and it is probable that Doulton Carara, similar to that used in the Savoy extension, will be adopted. Some of the prime movers in the scheme, however, favour green, the Islam colour, and it is possible that a combination of white and green will eventually be approved. In any case, the domes will be gilded in a similar way to those of the world-famous Taj Mahal at Agra, built by the Shah Jehan at a cost, it is said, of over three million pounds.
The building, which is estimated to cost about £100,000, will take about three years to erect. Operations are expected to he commen- ced shortly.

div.head: JOURNALIST AND MR. FINDLAY.
div.p: An amusing joke has been played by "Al Minbar” at the expense of Abou Shadi Bey, the Editor of "Al Zaher." The former paper recently announced that the Bey had had a "private interview” at Ramleh with Mr. Findlay. This piece of news had the desired effect, for it surmised that the Editor of “Al Zaher” had sought a private interview with the British Charge d’Affaires in order to make some revelations of astounding import- once, which mist compromise all his con- frères and betray the sacred cause of Egyptian Nationalism. All the dovecots of the vernacular newspaper world were fluttering with excite- meant as the what had or might have transpired at this moment to what had or might have transpired at this momentous interview, and there was a great danger of “Al Zaher” being inextricably compromised in the eyes of its readers. About Shad Bey was in a great state of alarm, and he has sent telegrams to the native papers wherein he swears upon his honour that he has never set eyes on Mr. Findlay, nor has he the slightest acquaintance with the British Chargé d'Afiaires, and that the juxtaposition of his residence with the summer quarters of the British Agency is simply and solely due to the fact that a member of his family is ill and so he is living at Ramleh for the sake of his relative’s health.

“Al Zaher’s” Alexandria correspondent in- forms us that the object of “al Minbar” in spreading this false report as to the secret interview between About Shadi Bey and the British Chargé d’Affaires was the bring the Editor of “Al Zaher” under the suspicion of receiving a subvention from the British Agency.

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: At Alexandria yesterday one plague patient was discharged from hospital cured.
At Suez one death from plague occurred outside the hospital, and a European was admitted to hospital.

div.head: EGYPTIAN GOVERNMENT TENDERS.
div.p: The Cairo correspondent of "African Engineerirg” writes :—

Your remarks about the handicapping of the British manufacturer in Egypt, owing to the laxity of Government contracts, are to the point, and in this respect I would mention that properly drawn specifications would be of the utmost value to English firms. The weakest point about Government specifications, apart from the great mistake in specifying the metri- cal measurements, is that the contractors are often allowed too much latitude in purchasing, which often results in their filling up their tenders with cheap Continental staff. Why do not your British engineers—who, in all conscience, are wealthy enough - take the trouble to exert a little political influence to bring about the requisite pressure on the Egyptian authorities?

div.head: COTTON.
div.p: Collinge Brothers telegraph from New York to-days :-
Weekly Bureau Crop accounts are generally favourable Carolinas Oklahoma crop prospects somewhat less favourable.

div.head: THE BRINDISI ROUTE.
P & O EXPRESS SERVICE
div.p: Major General H. Mansfield writes to the "Times" under date August 3 :— "Perhaps you will find space in your paper for a short account of the experiences of the passengers who arrived at Brindisi from Port Said by P. and O. steamer on July 26, as it may prove of interest to travellers. Owing to the break- down of the railway somewhere near Modane, the P. and O. special train to Calais had to be diverted viâ Genoa and Marseilles, thus caus- ing a delay of some five or six hours, which was, of course, unavoidable. This delay was further increased, on arrival of the train at Villenenve, by the necessity for repairing one of the ‘wagons-lits’ and for replacing a mail van which was unfit to be sent on. This further delay might have been avoided had proper precautions been taken for the inspec- tion of the train at Brindisi before despatch; and the conductors of the train were loud in their criticisms of the ramshackle condition of many of the vehicles. Several of the passengers were shown the defects and can corroborate my statements. On arrival at Dover, at about 10 p.m., the passengers were informed that their luggage, which was registered through to Victoria, would be at once examined and handed over to them and that they would have to get to London as best they could. The 9 p.m. train having left, the passengers had the option of proceeding to London by the 1.45 am. train to Cannon-street or by the 3.45 a,m. train to Victoria. Some 15 to 20 passengers were therefore left with their luggage on the pier whilst application was first made for a special train to the local railway authorities and then through them to thou at Victoria Station. The reply was a flat refusal to make a special train available unless paid for by the passengers themselves, in addition to the ordinary first-class fare already paid. The passengers, therefore, spent the middle of the night on the Dover pier, in the railway station, or in empty railway carriages. These passengers were travelling on special through tickets from Bombay or Port Said to Victoria and their heavy baggage was registered thorough to Victoria ; and, rightly or wrongly, there is an impression that the issue of snob tickets by the P. and 0. Company implies an obligation on the part of the com- pany to provide a connected service by rail and steamer throughout the journey without avoid- able delay. The company, however, disclaims any responsibility for the delay to passengers, as does also the Sooth-Eastern and Chatham Railway Company, the latter stating that when the Indian mails arrive at Dover on Saturday night they are detained there, at the request of the Postmaster-General, until Sunday morn- ing, and that as no one suggested payment for the necessary expense of a special train, ‘the railway company was in no way to blame for the delay experienced at Dover by passen- gers who had come by the P. and 0. service.’ I contend that the P. and 0. Company, who were, of course, aware of the delay to the special train, should have authorized the railway com- pany to forward the passengers by special train on arrival at Dover ; and as they repudiate responsibility in the matter, I think it only fair to warn travellers of what they have to risk in travelling by this service, especially in bad weather in the winter.”

The following letter has been sent to the "Times” in reply to the above complaints :— Sir,—I observe a letter in “The Times” of Saturday touching what is called the P. and O. Brindisi service, in which the writer appears to express himself as if a casual breakdown on the Italian railway system was a thing of everyday occurrence, against the consequences of which the public required to be gravely warned.

With this apparent suggestion there is mixed up a complaint that this company did not at their expense order special arrangements to be carried out in order to remedy in some partionlars the consequences of this excep- tional accident. But the position of the company vis-à-vis to the Continental and English railways ought to be sufficiently clear to any one who considers the matter. It is true that the company makes a con- siderable sacrifice in order to render the through service from the East via Brindisi as cheap as the service via Marseilles, and those who choose to travel by the first-named route have the advantage of saving two days on the through journey. But in issuing tickets for the land portion of the journey this company can only act as the mandatory of the railways for the convenience of their customers, and necessarily without profit, control, or respon- sibility, in respect to the land journey. If our passengers are at any time aggrieved by the action of the railways, we are at all times willing to lay their representations be- fore the companies concerned ; but there our duty begins and ends.
I am, Sir, your obedient servant,
J. M. SHIELDS, for Secretary.
Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, 129, Leadenball street, E C. Aug. 28.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Earl of Halsbury, late Lord Chancellor, accompanied by Lady Halsbury, will spend the winter in Egypt. They leave England in December, and will pass the early part of the season on the Nile at Luxor and Assouan.
H E. Fakhry Pasha, Minister of Public Works, arrived yesterday at Alexandria on his return from Europe via Port Said.

Little importance is attached in military quarters to the report that Lord Kitchener is to succeed Lord Grefell in the Irish command. Commander of the Irish Forces is one of several possible positions which Lord Kitchener may be offered, but the Pall Mall authorities declare that no selection has yet been made, and is not likely to be made for some time.

His lordship was appointed to the Indian command in November, 1902, for five years, so that his term has still fourteen months to run, and there is, moreover, no reason why it should not be extended for another year.

George Nungovich Bey is interested in, the construction of a large hotel at Paris, Rue de Presbourg, near the Arch de Triomphe de l ’Etoile. Nungovich Bey is coining for a short stay to San Stefano from Cairo, and will return subsequently to Paris with his family.
The S.Y. Dragon, which left Alexandra for Smyrna on Monday, belongs to Mr. Rees.

The recent spell of hot weather had turned everyone’s thoughts to cooling beverages. We cannot, however, be too careful of what we drink. Mineral waters are the generally ac- cepted method of quenching our thirsts, but whose mineral waters to drink is another question. We cannot do better than recom- mend to our readers the products of Mr. N. Spathis, the well known merchant and mineral waters manufacturer of Cairo and Alexandria. His works are on the latest and most up-to-date design ; every precaution known to modem science in the manufacture of high-class mineral and aerated waters is carefully regarded. The water is, filtered by Pasteur’s filters and the other ingredients used in the manufacture of his popular and greatly appreciated soda water, lemonade, ginger beer, lime juice and soda, lemon squash, etc., are of the very finest quality.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)

Le marché reprend anjourd'hui de la fer- meté. Londres étant venu avec 1/2 livre de hausse pour la National Bank, celle-ci remonle de 26 1/2 à 26 15/16. De son côté, l'Agricole qui est en baisse à Londres n'en hausse pas moins ici de 9 23/32 à 9 27/32 à la suite d'une bonne demands.

On fait de nouveau courir le bruit de la fusion de la Salt and Soda avec la Port Said Salt Association. C'est à quoi probablement il faut attribuer la reprise de 1 shelling de la Salt and Soda à 21/3-21/6.
Très soutenue la Cassa di Sconto nouvelle gagne encore 50 centimes à 220.
Des offres continuues provenant du Caire et ne rencontrant pas de contre-partie font baisser les Nungovich Hotels de 17 9/16 à 17 1/4.
La Delta Land s'avance à 3 1/2 vendeurs.
Tandis que la Building Lands of Egypt perd 3/32 à 5, le Trust se raffermit toujours da vantage à 1 7/16 acheteurs.
Le Comptoir demeure stationnaire aux cours antérieurs, excepté la part de fondateur qui réactionne à 45 1/2.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
div.p: Le Caire, 5 Septembre.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres vient d'être réduit de 1/8 à 3 3/8 pout cent. Hier au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé est resté in- varié à 87 1/8, de même que l'Unifiée à 104 3/4. La National Bank est demeurée inchangée à 26 3/4, l'Agricole à 9 7/8, le Daira à 16 3/4 et la Delta Light à 11 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien est restée stationnaire à 760. La Banque d'Athenes a gagné 1 franc à 142.

Ce matin, notre marché des valeurs a mani- festé, au début, d'assez bonnes dispositions, mais un vent de réaction n'a pas tardé à souffler sur la cote, principalement sur les valeurs qui avaient bénéficié ces jours derniers d'une avance.

Ainsi, la National Bank, qui a atteint, à l'ouverture, 26 3/4, a été ramenée à 26 1/2, vendeurs, pour clôturer à ce prix. L'Agricole a rétrogradé à 9 11/26-3/4. La Banque d'Athè- nes et la Barque d'Orient se sont alourdies à 140 et 131-132. Le Comptoir Financier est revenu à 6 11/16.

L'action Crédit Foncier s'est maintenue à 759-760; l'obligation à lots ancienne a pro- gressé à 339 et la nouvelle à 271-272. La Nile Land s'est raffermia à 13 7/8; l'Enterprise and Development à 12 1/8-3/16 et la part de
fondateur à 19 3/4. Le Wardan Estate a gagné 1/16 à 7 3/16 et les Improvements 1/16 à 4 13/16.

L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Tra- vaux a été recherchée à 4 5/16-3/8. L'action Allotment est retombée à 3 3/8 et la part de fondateur à 129. La part de fondateur Menza- leh a été demandée ` 107. Les Automobiles ont été moins bien tenus à 5 3/8.
Daus le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont perdu 3/8 à 17 1/2. Par contre, les Egyptian se sont consolidés à 6 7/16 et les Splendid à 3 5/8. Les National ont reculé à 3 7/8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont avancé à 3 3/8-7/16. Les Hooker ont été demandés à 0 7/8-15/16. Les Salt and Soda ont progressé à 20 sh. 3, les New Egyptian à 29 sh. 6 et les Cotton Mills à 6 sh. 3. Les Abdy ont fléchi à 1 3/16-1/4. Les Contructions ont été échangées à 1 1/2.

L'assemblé générale extraordinaire de la Building Lands of Egypt Co., tenue hier dans l'après midi au siège social à Alexandria, a voté, à l'unanimité, la fusion avec l'Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd. (Glymenopoulo). 29,559 actions (soit plus des 3/4 du capital) étaient représentées, donnaut 1,457 voix.
MM. Edouard Cumbo et Jules Lombardo, tous deux administrateurs du Trust, feront partie du conseil de la Building, dont les membres seront portés ainsi à sept.

A la suite de la fusion des deux Sociétés, il sera créé 60,000 nouvelles actions Building Lands de £4, qui seront échangées à leur valeur nominale contre les 200,000 actions du Trust, soit 3 Building Lands contre 10 Trust.

En outre, par suite de l'abandon de la somme de £24,000, consenti par M. Glyme- nopoulo lui-même et non parle Trust, comme cela avait été dit par erreur, il n'u aura plus lieu d'émetrre les 7,500 actions Building dont il y avait eu précédemment le projet pour le remboursement des indemnités; le montant de ces indemnités à payer auc anciens admi- nistrateurs, directeurs, secrétaires, etc. du Trust sera réduit à £14,000 seulement.

Le président de l'assemblés a ajouté quel- ques mots faisant ressortir la situation excep- tionnellement bonne du Trust, dont les pro- priétés auraint une sperficie totale de près de 3/4 de million de pics, situés dans les environs les plus prospèces de la ville.
Hier, à la Bourse d'Alexandria les Building Lands ont avancé de1/16 à 5 1/16-1/8 et les Glymenopoulo à 1 7/16-15/32.
"The Egyptian Gazette" d'hier donne les renseignments suivants sur la situation de la Splendid Hotels Co.

"Bien que les recettes du premier exercice se soient élevées à £22,000, les bénéfices nets n'ont été que de £1,500. Ces résultats peu satisfaisants sont dus en partie à la mauvaise administration de l'ancien directeur du New Khedivial Hotel et en partie à la fermeture de hôtel pendant une grande partie de l'annee à cause des agrandissements qui ont été faits.

"L'exercice courant se presente, heureuse- ment, sous de meilleurs auspices. Un nouvean directeur de la plus haute compétence, M. Reinsperger, a été engagé sur la recommanda= tion du M. Baehler, et l'exploitation se fait aujourd'hui sur un pied économique.

"Les 6,000 pics carrés de terrain et l'immeu- ble du New Khedivial Hotel avaient été ache- tés par la Société à la famille Menasce au prix de L.E. 60,000. Les additions qui y ont été faites ont coûté L.E. 12,00. Or, la valeur actuelle de la propriété dépasse certainement le capital de la Société qui est de L.E. 90,000"
Les recettes des Tramways d'Alexandrie pour la semaine au 1er Semtembre courant se sont élevées à L.E. 1,980 contre 1,633 eu 1905, soit enaugmentation de L.E. 347.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Janvier 1906 ont atteint la somme de L.E. 53,854 contre 45,551 en 1905, soit en plus-value de L.E. 8,303 pour l'exercice courant.
Les recettes de l'Alexandria Ramleh Railway Co. pour la semaine su 1er Septembre se chif frent par L.E. 1,534 contre 1,263 en 1905 soit en augmentation de L.E. 271.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Octobre sont de L.E. 57,377 contre 46,125 pour l'exer- cice précédent, soit en plus-value de L.E. 11,252.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à le connaissance du public qu'elle dispose de quinze postes d'apprentis vacants au service de la comptabi- lité et du contrôle.
Un examen aora lieu à cet effet au Bureau Central de la comptabilité le 14 Septembre courant à 9 h. a.m.
Les candidats qui seront choisis seront payés à raison de L.E. 3 par mois. Après six mois d'essai et s'ils donnent satisfaction, cette paie sera angmentée suivant leurs mérites.
Toute demande doit être accompagnée d'une feuille timbrée de P.T. 3 et adressée avant le 14 Septembre courant:
A Mr. le Controleur Général de la Compta- bilité des Chemins de fer de l'Etat, au Caire.
Les candidats devront joindre à leurs de- mandes:
1. Un certificat de nationalité égypti
2. Un certificat de naissance constatant qu'ils ne sont pas âgés de plus de 22 ans ni moins de 18 ans.
3. Le certificat d'études primaires émanant du Ministère de l'Instruction Publique et non antérieur à 1903.
4. Leur avis de liconciement s'ils ont déjà été au service du Gouvernement.
5. Un certificat de bonne vie et moeurs.
Le Caire, le 1er Septembre 1906. 28,431-2-1

div.head: Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs.
AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a l'honneur d'informer le Public que, dans le but de prévenie toute contagion de rage, des instructions viennent d'être données à ses agents de tenir la main à la stricte application de l'Art. 81 du Tarif des Voyageurs qui prescit que les chiens doivent être, durant leur transport, installés dans les fourgons et taxés à moitié prix de la III classe.

Toutefois si les voyageurs d'un même com- partiment sont unanimement d'accord pour tolérer la présence d'un chien avec son proprié- taire, l'Administration n'y objectera pas pourvu que le prix de son transport ait été régulière- ment payé.
Le Caire, le 3 Septembre 1906. 28441-2-1
